channel.title: Buzzing on The Wall Street Journal
channel.description: 用中文浏览华尔街日报热门报道

item.title: Wang Jixian, a software programmer from Beijing, is one of the last Chinese nationals still in Ukraine. Instead of fleeing, he is posting videos in what he calls a two-front battle: against the Russian invasion, and against his own compatriots back home. https://t.co/lCeSmqvKUs

From @WSJopinion: The attempt by Biden to assign blame for the acceleration of prices that began just over a year ago to a war that began just under three weeks ago is remarkable for its cynicism, its dishonesty and its desperation, writes @gerardtbaker https://t.co/MYOALOSUBq

Watch: Vladimir Putin and Xi Jinping have become close in the past decade, toasting with vodka and exchanging friendship medals. As the West sanctions Russia over its invasion of Ukraine, China could help, but only to a certain extent. https://t.co/C5vifBRfnW
The SEC is investigating the Big Four accounting firms for potential conflicts of interest that could influence their audits, people familiar say https://t.co/AIablJcCHN
A year ago, China’s Xi Jinping appeared unassailable. Since then, thin cracks have emerged in his power. https://t.co/pdccHvdrKz
The woman who burst onto the set of Russia’s most-watched news program Monday evening with an antiwar poster was fined for protest violation https://t.co/gv5irkK8eh
Actress and “Passing” writer-director-producer Rebecca Hall talks about growing as an artist during a time of upheaval and uncertainty. #WSJWomen https://t.co/tMxVXJmEDC

France is ready to grant asylum to the Russian woman who interrupted a live broadcast on Russian state television brandishing a poster against the war in Ukraine, French President Emmanuel Macron said https://t.co/sxYB1MxSUs
Breaking: Fox News cameraman Pierre Zakrzewski was killed on assignment in Ukraine when his vehicle was struck by fire near Kyiv, the network said https://t.co/ACNxwWoBmX
Chernobyl, site of the world’s worst nuclear-power disaster, is now the harrowing scene of 200 trapped, exhausted Ukrainian staffers forced to work nonstop at Russian gunpoint https://t.co/9EkFflUWZg
Saudi Arabia is in talks to price its oil sales to China in yuan, people familiar with the matter said. The move would dent the U.S. dollar's dominance of the oil market. https://t.co/cqwq1xeoYF

Russia's Investigative Committee was probing whether to charge the woman who protested against the war on Russian TV on Monday, Russian state-news agency TASS reported. Human-rights lawyers said the protester's whereabouts are unknown. https://t.co/kXft89oOOg
Oil prices slid below $100 a barrel after China imposed Covid-19 lockdowns, erasing much of the surge since Russia invaded Ukraine https://t.co/cLOfP1D6Aj
U.S. national security adviser Jake Sullivan met in Rome with China’s top diplomat, Yang Jiechi, in effort to de-escalate the crisis https://t.co/l8mpj8L5lc
A group of European leaders headed to Kyiv to meet with President Zelensky as Russia bombarded the Ukrainian capital and fighting raged in the city’s outskirts https://t.co/W0rdULII9R
A Florida judge ruled Monday that certain records in the investigation of Bob Saget's death won't be made public, in accordance with his family's wishes https://t.co/J2SOTOra78

Foxconn, the biggest assembler of Apple iPhones, is in talks with Saudi Arabia about jointly building a $9 billion multipurpose facility that could make microchips, electric-vehicle components and other electronics like displays https://t.co/zm57QOgez6
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/zmdbpfthNe

“The trading system as we’ve known it, with the World Trade Organization at its core and with a basic set of rules that everyone traded under, is coming apart.” Russia is just the latest blow. https://t.co/u6k2LiVBy3

German insurer and asset manager Allianz is no longer underwriting new insurance business in Russia and is "decisively" reducing its exposure to Russia "in an orderly manner," a spokeswoman said https://t.co/woILGVXute

Russia fired more than two dozen cruise missiles from long-range bombers flying over its own airspace during its Sunday attack on a Ukrainian military training center near the Polish border, a senior U.S. defense official said Monday https://t.co/zETlI1gy8S

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky plans to take his case for more military gear directly to Congress Wednesday, just as many lawmakers are trying to prod the White House to move more aggressively to repel Russia’s invasion https://t.co/WMGUZN2U5a
The pregnant woman whose image went global as she was stretchered from a bombed maternity hospital in Ukraine died along with her baby, according to the Associated Press https://t.co/1g4HJWHWTa

National security adviser Jake Sullivan pressed a top Chinese official over China’s alignment with Russia during what U.S. officials said was an intense, seven-hour meeting that included discussion of the Russian invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/pXsNHEIAQX

Citigroup is pulling further back from Russia, saying it would now exit other businesses on top of the retail bank it had planned to shed, and wouldn't be adding new business in Russia https://t.co/oc1CE1ZJmc

A woman ran onto the set of an evening news program on Russian state television’s flagship Channel One on Monday holding a poster reading: “No war. Stop the war. Don’t believe propaganda. They lie to you here. Russians against war.” https://t.co/X6bqm4w7xO

Diplomatic efforts to end Russia’s war in Ukraine showed no signs of progress on Monday as fighting for the capital intensified, with Russian missiles destroying an aircraft factory and an apartment building in Kyiv https://t.co/EuOGvPwD2C

From @WSJopinion: Americans need relief, and one thing stands in the way: Biden’s unwillingness to reverse course on his administration’s commitment to put the American oil-and-gas industry out of business at the consumer’s expense, writes Harold Hamm https://t.co/AGKDuo17rB

Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a law allowing Russian airlines to retain and operate planes rented from foreign aircraft lessors for use on domestic flights, according to state news agency TASS https://t.co/JUxJrJxZUw

Saudi Arabia has invited Chinese President Xi Jinping to visit Riyadh as the kingdom looks to deepen ties with Beijing amid strained relations with Washington, people familiar with the plan said https://t.co/m5Bnxh7pIq

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky plans to take his case for more military gear directly to Congress Wednesday, just as many lawmakers are trying to prod the White House to move more aggressively to repel Russia’s invasion https://t.co/0YDSDNkcxM

A woman ran onto the set of an evening news program on Russian state television's flagship Channel One on Monday holding a poster reading: “No war. Stop the war. Don’t believe propaganda. They lie to you here. Russians against war.” https://t.co/851vIRCEEr

Israeli Prime Minister Naftali Bennett continued his mediation efforts Monday night between Russia and Ukraine. Israel has strong ties with both Kyiv and Moscow and has so far unsuccessfully tried to act as a peace broker between the two sides. https://t.co/OyzOqBt2Kx

National security adviser Jake Sullivan pressed a top Chinese official over China’s alignment with Russia during what U.S. officials said was an intense, seven-hour meeting that included discussion of the Russian invasion of Ukraine https://t.co/hYKUHkaEwE

Saudi Arabia has invited Chinese President Xi Jinping to visit Riyadh as the kingdom looks to deepen ties with Beijing amid strained relations with Washington, people familiar with the plan said https://t.co/uceX3PPWAX

The app allowing people to access the satellite-based internet service provided by Elon Musk’s SpaceX became the most downloaded app from the Apple App Store in Ukraine on Sunday, and it remained in the top spot as of Monday, according to Sensor Tower https://t.co/lUjVrY9FgL

Russian President Vladimir Putin has signed a law allowing Russian airlines to retain and operate planes rented from foreign aircraft lessors for use on domestic flights, according to state news agency TASS https://t.co/pZQqMK0zfv

Elon Musk said his two companies Tesla and SpaceX are facing substantial inflationary pressure and that he won't sell his cryptocurrency holdings amid high inflation. "I still own & won’t sell my bitcoin, ethereum or doge," the billionaire said. https://t.co/gm5jvtGI3k

Faced with mounting Western pressure, China is eager to be seen as trying to help prevent the Ukraine crisis from deepening. But Beijing’s reluctance to distance itself from Moscow is limiting any role it can play toward getting Russia to back down. https://t.co/CCLklI5OOg

From @WSJopinion: No one wants a broader war. But as Russia escalates, Biden and NATO had better be prepared to fight one. A reckless or desperate Putin may give them no choice. https://t.co/EcUC0Bal3Z
From @WSJopinion: A show of force inside Ukraine would save lives and deprive Putin of the ability to dictate events, writes Ludovic Hood https://t.co/4VVzeL7rgk

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky will address Congress virtually on Wednesday, U.S. House and Senate leaders said, as the Russian incursion into Ukraine intensifies and President Biden grapples with how to respond https://t.co/2eJ8DWYLah
Pfizer said it will donate profits from its Russian business to programs providing humanitarian aid to help the people of Ukraine https://t.co/L5M34OkaNA
Russia’s invasion of Ukraine threatens a big portion of the world’s wheat supply and points to further inflation of food prices #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/B4Pl2z7Urc https://t.co/4t01NVwS0s
Russian forces are killing civilians and looting stores and homes across occupied parts of southern Ukraine, residents said https://t.co/QPjSo1fOjJ
Watch: Javelins, Stingers and TB2 drones work are crucial to Ukrainian forces. We explain how these weapons work. https://t.co/D1pd8RN3bY
Take an early look at the front page of The Wall Street Journal https://t.co/5xQPDPcm8q https://t.co/ddV9Ds9Akg

McDonald’s, Coca-Cola and IBM are among those warned by Russian prosecutors that leaders could be arrested if they criticize the Kremlin and assets seized if companies withdraw from the country #WSJWhatsNow https://t.co/705yn9gIR5 https://t.co/6XRGbpd3KI

Robert Iger spent decades helming a company known for its animated characters. For his next act, the former Disney boss is backing a startup that celebrities and others are using to create avatars for the much-hyped metaverse. https://t.co/JWxquwfDJb
The pregnant woman whose image went global as she was stretchered from a bombed maternity hospital in Ukraine died along with her baby, according to the Associated Press https://t.co/CCW67tPnHc
